chants.title: Baye Fall Chant unplugged
chants.content: This is a recording of Baye Fall chanting recorded in Diourbel, Senegal on July 22, 2011. The Baye Falls are a sub-sect of the Mouride Islamic Brotherhood. This was recorded outside the compound of a Peace Corps Volunteer serving in Senegal.

dances.title: Change of Command Ceremony - United States Army Africa - 10 June 2010
dances.content: www.usaraf.army.mil Hogg takes command of U.S. Army Africa 10 June 2010 - By Rick Scavetta, U.S. Army Africa Public Affairs VICENZA, Italy – During a ceremony today at Caserma Ederle’s Hoekstra Field, Maj. Gen. David R. Hogg assumed command of U.S. Army Africa. Gen. William E. Ward, commanding general of U.S. Africa Command presided over the ceremony, which signaled the departure of outgoing commander, Maj. Gen. William B. Garrett III. Hogg, who recently served as deputy commanding general of Combined Security Transition Command-Afghanistan, said he is delighted to become part of the Vicenza military community. “After 29 years of service and six overseas assignments to include Germany, Panama and Belgium, this is our first opportunity to be in Italy,” Hogg said. “We are absolutely thrilled to be here.” Hogg said he is excited to be a part of U.S. Army Africa, the Army's newest service component command, challenged with developing relationships with land forces in Africa and supporting U.S. Army efforts on the African continent. Ward reminded the crowd that U.S. Army Africa has accomplished some great things since Dec. 2008, when it began its transformation to becoming the Army service component command for U.S. Africa Command. “In that short time, the command has formed, grown, and matured into an active and effective outfit and has established strong strategic relationships with the ground forces in Africa,” Ward said. “U.S. Army Africa not only succeeded, they excelled. In fact, they thrived on the opportunities they were given.” Garrett took command of the Southern European Task Force in 2008. He commanded SETAF throughout its transformation to U.S. Army Africa. Garrett now heads to Iraq, where he will serve as the chief of staff, U.S. Forces Iraq. “We look forward to building upon the systems that Maj. Gen. Garrett and Mrs. Garrett have developed,” Hogg said. “We are truly thankful for the warm welcome that we have received from the community and, especially, the Garretts.” Source: https://www.flickr.com/photos/36281822@N08/4687155133 Uploader: US Army Africa

metadata.title: Change of Command Ceremony - United States Army Africa - 10 June 2010

Hogg, who recently served as deputy commanding general of Combined Security Transition Command-Afghanistan, said he is delighted to become part of the Vicenza military community. “After 29 years of service and six overseas assignments to include Germany, Panama and Belgium, this is our first opportunity to be in Italy,” Hogg said. “We are absolutely thrilled to be here.” Hogg said he is excited to be a part of U.S. Army Africa, the Army's newest service component command, challenged with developing relationships with land forces in Africa and supporting U.S. Army efforts on the African continent. In fact, they thrived on the opportunities they were given.” Garrett took command of the Southern European Task Force in 2008. He commanded SETAF throughout its transformation to U.S. Army Africa. Garrett now heads to Iraq, where he will serve as the chief of staff, U.S. Forces Iraq. “We look forward to building upon the systems that Maj. Gen. Garrett and Mrs. Garrett have developed,” Hogg said. “We are truly thankful for the warm welcome that we have received from the community and, especially, the Garretts.” Source: https://www.flickr.com/photos/36281822@N08/4687155133 Uploader: US Army Africa

dances.title: An International Study of American Roads
dances.content: This moving image includes T.H. MacDonald, Chief, Bureau of Public Roads, who introduces the picture. Reel 1 shows Government buildings in Washington, D.C.; Mount Vernon and the Mt. Vernon Memorial Highway under construction; maps showing the route followed by the touring international delegates; buses leaving Washington, D.C., and passing through Miami, Florida, and St. Simons Island, Georgia; antebellum mansions in the South; and a Black boy dancing. Reel 2 shows views of North Carolina's Great Smoky Mountains; Virginia's Natural Bridge; Philadelphia's Independence Hall; Valley Forge; the Philadelphia-Camden toll bridge; the Holland Tunnel; the New York City skyline and crowds in the city; the recently completed Empire State Building; airplanes over the George Washington Bridge; boulevards in Westchester County; the Boston Post Road to New York City; Niagara Falls; Duluth, Minnesota, and iron mines nearby; a school children's pageant honoring the delegates; a war dance performed by Sac Indians In Iowa; Chicago's Lake Shore Drive; a University of Michigan football game in Ann Arbor; the Dodge Auto plant in Detroit; and the Detroit-Windsor tunnel. Reel 3 maps the interrelation between Federal and State roads using North Carolina roads as an example. Charts depict the growth of auto registrations, 1900-1930. The moving image also shows the hand construction of roads, types of road machinery, and a concrete road under construction. In reel 4, a road bed is prepared and a dirt road graded. A picture sequence shows a car mired in dirt road in 1918, a gravel road in 1920, a bituminous road in 1925, and a concrete highway in 1930. Includes panoramic views of bridges, highways, and traffic. Reel 5 shows types of vehicles using the roads, a motel, a congested highway outside a city, a horse race, a Greyhound bus in motion, and the loading of furniture into a van. Reel 6 shows the truck transport of goods from a railroad station, livestock in trucks, the loading of vegetables into a truck, solid-tired milk trucks, highways of various widths, banked curves and guard rails, over and underpasses, roads in Indiana, Florida, and Ohio, a motorcycle police patrol, a patrolman unsnarling a traffic jam, snowplows in action, the Statue of Liberty, and the U.S. Marine Corps band. Description courtesy of the National Archives. National Archives Identifier: 7364
dances.authorName: United States. Department of Agriculture. Federal Extension Service.

Includes panoramic views of bridges, highways, and traffic. Reel 6 shows the truck transport of goods from a railroad station, livestock in trucks, the loading of vegetables into a truck, solid-tired milk trucks, highways of various widths, banked curves and guard rails, over and underpasses, roads in Indiana, Florida, and Ohio, a motorcycle police patrol, a patrolman unsnarling a traffic jam, snowplows in action, the Statue of Liberty, and the U.S. Marine Corps band.
